title: Amos Chapter 6 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Amos chapter 6 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Amos Chapter 6 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Amos Chapter 6.

questions.question: According to Amos 6:1, who are described as 'at ease in Zion' and trusting in the mountain of Samaria?
options: They that are named chief of the nations
The Philistines
The people of Hamath
The inhabitants of Calneh
questions.correctAnswer: They that are named chief of the nations
questions.explanation: Amos 6:1 describes those at ease in Zion and trusting in the mountain of Samaria as 'named chief of the nations'.

questions.question: What places does Amos 6:2 instruct to visit to compare their greatness with Israel's kingdoms?
options: Calneh, Hamath, and Gath
Jerusalem, Bethlehem, and Nazareth
Babylon, Nineveh, and Tyre
Egypt, Moab, and Edom
questions.correctAnswer: Calneh, Hamath, and Gath
questions.explanation: Amos 6:2 mentions going to Calneh, then Hamath the great, and then down to Gath of the Philistines to compare their kingdoms.

questions.question: What do those in Amos 6:4 lie upon and stretch themselves upon?
options: Beds of ivory and couches
Mats of straw and benches
Stone slabs and wooden chairs
Beds of gold and thrones
questions.correctAnswer: Beds of ivory and couches
questions.explanation: Amos 6:4 states they lie on beds of ivory and stretch themselves upon their couches.

questions.question: According to Amos 6:5, to what sound do they chant and what kind of instruments do they invent?
options: To the sound of the viol and instruments like David
To the sound of the trumpet and cymbals
To the sound of the harp and flute
To the sound of drums and tambourines
questions.correctAnswer: To the sound of the viol and instruments like David
questions.explanation: Amos 6:5 says they chant to viols and invent instruments of music like David.

questions.question: What are they not grieved for, according to Amos 6:6?
options: The affliction of Joseph
The destruction of Samaria
The famine in the land
The exile of the captives
questions.correctAnswer: The affliction of Joseph
questions.explanation: Amos 6:6 states they are not grieved for the affliction of Joseph.

questions.question: What consequence does Amos 6:7 say will happen to those who stretched themselves?
options: They shall go captive and their banquet removed
They will be exalted and praised
They shall inherit the land
They will be healed and restored
questions.correctAnswer: They shall go captive and their banquet removed
questions.explanation: Amos 6:7 says those who stretched themselves shall go captive and their banquet shall be removed.

questions.question: What has the Lord sworn by Himself according to Amos 6:8?
options: He abhors the excellency of Jacob and hates his palaces
He loves the palaces of Jacob and blesses them
He will protect the city and its inhabitants
He will forgive the sins of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: He abhors the excellency of Jacob and hates his palaces
questions.explanation: Amos 6:8 declares that God abhors Jacob's excellency and hates his palaces.

questions.question: What will happen if ten men remain in one house, according to Amos 6:9?
options: They shall die
They shall be saved
They shall be blessed
They shall be taken captive
questions.correctAnswer: They shall die
questions.explanation: Amos 6:9 states that if ten men remain in one house, they shall die.

questions.question: In Amos 6:10, what does the man who burns the bones ask when removing them from the house?
options: Is there yet any with thee?
Have all departed?
Is the house clean?
Who is left inside?
questions.correctAnswer: Is there yet any with thee?
questions.explanation: Amos 6:10 describes the man asking if any remain inside, 'Is there yet any with thee?'.

questions.question: True or False: Amos 6:11 says the LORD will smite both the great house and the little house with breaches and clefts.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Amos 6:11 confirms the LORD will smite the great house with breaches and the little house with clefts.

questions.question: What does Amos 6:12 compare to illustrate the absurdity of turning judgment into gall?
options: Horses running on rock and plowing with oxen
Birds flying without wings
Fish walking on dry land
Trees growing without roots
questions.correctAnswer: Horses running on rock and plowing with oxen
questions.explanation: Amos 6:12 asks if horses will run on rock or oxen plow there, illustrating the folly of corrupted judgment.

questions.question: True or False: Amos 6:13 mentions people rejoicing in a thing of nought and claiming strength by their own horns.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Amos 6:13 describes those who rejoice in nothing and say they have taken horns by their own strength.

questions.question: According to Amos 6:14, what will the LORD raise up against the house of Israel?
options: A nation that shall afflict them
A mighty king to save them
A prophet to guide them
An army of angels to protect them
questions.correctAnswer: A nation that shall afflict them
questions.explanation: Amos 6:14 says the LORD will raise up a nation to afflict the house of Israel.

questions.question: True or False: Amos 6:3 describes people who put far away the evil day and cause the seat of violence to come near.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Amos 6:3 says they put away the evil day and bring near the seat of violence.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Amos 6:6: 'That drink wine in bowls, and anoint themselves with the chief ________.'
options: ointments
fruits
sacrifices
robes
questions.correctAnswer: ointments
questions.explanation: Amos 6:6 mentions they anoint themselves with chief ointments.

medium.title: Amos Chapter 6 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Amos Chapter 6 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Amos 6:1 warn us about where to place our trust in daily life?
options: Trusting in God rather than worldly security
Relying on wealth and comfort above all
Putting confidence in political power
Seeking fame among nations
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting in God rather than worldly security
questions.explanation: Amos 6:1 warns those who are 'at ease in Zion' and trust in the 'mountain of Samaria'—symbols of worldly security and pride—rather than God. This teaches us to place trust in God and not in transient earthly powers. See also Amos 6:8, which shows God's displeasure with their misplaced confidence.

questions.question: According to Amos 6:4-6, what kind of lifestyle does God condemn, and what virtue does this warn us to practice?
options: Luxury and self-indulgence; practicing humility and care for others
Hard work and diligence; practicing rest and worship
Generosity and giving; practicing stewardship
Prayer and fasting; practicing perseverance
questions.correctAnswer: Luxury and self-indulgence; practicing humility and care for others
questions.explanation: Verses 4-6 describe those who 'lie upon beds of ivory' and 'drink wine in bowls,' indulging themselves while ignoring the suffering of others. This passage warns us to avoid self-indulgence and instead practice humility and compassion, reflecting God's heart for the afflicted (Amos 6:6).

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with pride because of their achievements. Based on Amos 6:13, what biblical truth would you share?
options: Do not boast in your own strength, for true power comes from God
Your achievements are proof of your superiority
Pride is a sign of righteousness
Your strength is enough to overcome all challenges
questions.correctAnswer: Do not boast in your own strength, for true power comes from God
questions.explanation: Amos 6:13 warns against rejoicing in 'a thing of nought' and boasting in 'horns by our own strength,' meaning human pride is misplaced. True strength and success come from God, who raises and humbles nations (Amos 6:14).

questions.question: What does Amos 6:3 teach us about the consequences of delaying repentance and ignoring evil?
options: Delaying the evil day only brings it closer
Ignoring evil makes it go away
Repentance can be delayed without consequence
Evil will never come near those who ignore it
questions.correctAnswer: Delaying the evil day only brings it closer
questions.explanation: Verse 3 says, 'Ye that put far away the evil day, and cause the seat of violence to come near,' indicating that ignoring or postponing repentance does not prevent judgment but makes it more imminent. This encourages us to repent promptly.

questions.question: How does Amos 6:7-8 illustrate the danger of complacency in the church community?
options: Complacency leads to judgment and loss of God's protection
Complacency brings peace and prosperity
Complacency is a sign of spiritual maturity
Complacency guarantees God's favor
questions.correctAnswer: Complacency leads to judgment and loss of God's protection
questions.explanation: Verses 7-8 describe how those who 'stretched themselves' in ease will be taken captive and the city delivered up, showing that complacency and pride result in God's judgment. This warns the church to remain vigilant and humble.

questions.question: True or False: Amos 6:6 teaches that personal indulgence is acceptable if one is not grieved by the suffering of others.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Amos 6:6 condemns those who indulge in wine and ointments 'but they are not grieved for the affliction of Joseph,' showing that personal indulgence without compassion is sinful.

questions.question: A believer is facing hardship and questions God's fairness. Based on Amos 6:9-10, what hope or warning can you share?
options: Judgment is certain for the unrepentant, even in the safety of home
God will always protect families from harm
Suffering is only for the wicked outside the home
God forgets those who call on Him
questions.correctAnswer: Judgment is certain for the unrepentant, even in the safety of home
questions.explanation: Verses 9-10 describe death and silence in the home during judgment, indicating that no place is safe for those who ignore God. This warns believers to repent and trust God even in trials.

questions.question: How does Amos 6:12 teach about the importance of integrity in judgment and righteousness?
options: Turning judgment into bitterness and righteousness into poison is condemned
Judgment and righteousness can be twisted for personal benefit
Only the strong need to follow righteousness
Integrity in judgment is optional
questions.correctAnswer: Turning judgment into bitterness and righteousness into poison is condemned
questions.explanation: Verse 12 condemns those who turn 'judgment into gall' and 'fruit of righteousness into hemlock,' warning against corrupting justice and righteousness. This teaches believers to uphold integrity and truth.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Amos 6:14 says, 'But, behold, I will raise up against you a __________, O house of Israel, saith the LORD the God of hosts; and they shall afflict you from the entering in of Hemath unto the river of the wilderness.'
options: nation
king
prophet
angel
questions.correctAnswer: nation
questions.explanation: Amos 6:14 clearly states that God will raise up a 'nation' against Israel as a form of judgment, symbolizing consequences for their disobedience and complacency.

questions.question: What practical lesson about stewardship can be drawn from Amos 6:4, where people 'eat the lambs out of the flock' and 'calves out of the midst of the stall'?
options: Misusing resources for personal luxury neglects care for others
Using resources quickly is always wise
Taking all for oneself pleases God
Resources are meant solely for personal enjoyment
questions.correctAnswer: Misusing resources for personal luxury neglects care for others
questions.explanation: Verse 4 criticizes those who consume valuable resources selfishly, neglecting justice and care for the community. This teaches responsible stewardship and generosity.

questions.question: True or False: Amos 6:11 indicates that both the 'great house' and the 'little house' will face breaches and clefts as a result of God's judgment.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Amos 6:11 states that God will 'smite the great house with breaches, and the little house with clefts,' showing that no one is exempt from judgment due to complacency or sin.

questions.question: Based on Amos 6:5, what is the danger in imitating outward religious displays without true heart obedience?
options: Inventing instruments of music like David without righteousness is vain
Music and worship are always pleasing to God
Outward displays guarantee spiritual favor
Religious displays replace the need for obedience
questions.correctAnswer: Inventing instruments of music like David without righteousness is vain
questions.explanation: Verse 5 mentions those who 'chant to the sound of the viol' and invent music like David but neglect genuine righteousness, reminding us that outward worship cannot substitute true obedience.

questions.question: How does Amos 6:2 help us understand the error of comparing ourselves to others for security or pride?
options: It points out that other kingdoms are not necessarily better or greater
Other kingdoms are always superior
Comparison is the key to finding security
Pride in borders guarantees success
questions.correctAnswer: It points out that other kingdoms are not necessarily better or greater
questions.explanation: Verse 2 challenges Israel to consider other kingdoms and questions if they are better or have greater borders, warning against pride based on worldly status.

questions.question: What spiritual discipline can be encouraged by reflecting on Amos 6:10, where people must 'hold thy tongue' and 'may not make mention of the name of the LORD'?
options: Reverent fear and respect for God's name even in hardship
Ignoring God's name in difficult times
Speaking freely about God without reverence
Avoiding prayer during trials
questions.correctAnswer: Reverent fear and respect for God's name even in hardship
questions.explanation: Verse 10 depicts a situation where God's name cannot be openly mentioned due to devastation, encouraging believers to maintain reverence and respect for God's name.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to ignore the suffering of others while enjoying comfort. Based on Amos 6:6, what biblical truth should be shared?
options: Enjoying personal blessings without grief for others' affliction displeases God
Comfort justifies ignoring others' needs
Personal luxury is always a blessing from God
Suffering of others is unrelated to our spiritual life
questions.correctAnswer: Enjoying personal blessings without grief for others' affliction displeases God
questions.explanation: Amos 6:6 condemns those who indulge themselves but are 'not grieved for the affliction of Joseph,' teaching that true faith includes compassion and concern for others.

hard.title: Amos Chapter 6 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Amos Chapter 6.

questions.question: In Amos 6:1, the phrase 'mountain of Samaria' symbolizes what concept in the context of ancient Israel?
options: The political and religious pride of Israel
The geographical height of the city
The economic wealth of Samaria
The military strength of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: The political and religious pride of Israel
questions.explanation: Amos 6:1 uses 'mountain of Samaria' as a metaphor for Israel’s confidence and pride in their national and religious status, which the prophet condemns.

questions.question: Amos 6:2 mentions Calneh, Hamath, and Gath. What is the literary purpose of referencing these foreign cities?
options: To challenge Israel's belief in their superiority by comparing their kingdoms
To indicate trade partners of Israel
To provide a travel itinerary for the prophet
To highlight historical battles Israel fought
questions.correctAnswer: To challenge Israel's belief in their superiority by comparing their kingdoms
questions.explanation: Amos 6:2 questions Israel’s pride by comparing their power and borders with those of other ancient nations, undermining their claims to supremacy.

questions.question: What does 'put far away the evil day' in Amos 6:3 imply about the attitude of the people?
options: They are complacent and ignore coming judgment
They anticipate disaster and prepare for it
They celebrate festivals prematurely
They engage in idolatry
questions.correctAnswer: They are complacent and ignore coming judgment
questions.explanation: The phrase in Amos 6:3 indicates a postponement or denial of impending judgment, showing the people’s complacency toward divine warnings.

questions.question: In Amos 6:4-5, the imagery of 'beds of ivory' and 'viol' music serves as a critique of what aspect of Israelite society?
options: Luxury and self-indulgence
Religious devotion
Military preparedness
Agricultural prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: Luxury and self-indulgence
questions.explanation: Verses Amos 6:4-5 depict the elite’s indulgence in luxury and entertainment, reflecting moral decay and social injustice.

questions.question: The comparison to David in Amos 6:5 is primarily to emphasize what?
options: The invention of musical instruments
The misuse of cultural heritage for self-glorification
The establishment of the monarchy
The composition of psalms
questions.correctAnswer: The misuse of cultural heritage for self-glorification
questions.explanation: Amos 6:5 alludes to David’s musical innovations to highlight how the people misuse cultural achievements for vain celebrations rather than repentance.

questions.question: What does the term 'chief ointments' in Amos 6:6 likely refer to in the ancient Near Eastern context?
options: Expensive perfumes used by the elite
Medicinal herbs
Anointing oil for priests
Sacrificial offerings
questions.correctAnswer: Expensive perfumes used by the elite
questions.explanation: In Amos 6:6, 'chief ointments' refers to luxurious perfumes or oils signifying the lavish lifestyle of Israel’s upper class.

questions.question: According to Amos 6:7, what will happen to those who 'stretched themselves' in luxury?
options: They will be taken captive first
They will escape judgment
They will lead Israel to victory
They will repent and be forgiven
questions.correctAnswer: They will be taken captive first
questions.explanation: Amos 6:7 warns that those indulging in luxury will be the first to face exile and loss of privilege.

questions.question: In Amos 6:8, God says He 'abhors the excellency of Jacob.' What theological theme does this reflect?
options: Divine judgment against pride and false security
God’s rejection of Israel’s ethnicity
God’s preference for other nations
The end of the covenant with Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Divine judgment against pride and false security
questions.explanation: The verse emphasizes that God’s judgment targets Israel’s arrogance and misplaced confidence in their status, not their identity per se.

questions.question: Amos 6:9 describes a scenario where even ten men in one house will die. This type of imagery is an example of what literary device?
options: Hyperbole to emphasize the extent of destruction
Metaphor for spiritual death
Simile comparing death to a flood
Parable illustrating family loyalty
questions.correctAnswer: Hyperbole to emphasize the extent of destruction
questions.explanation: The verse uses hyperbolic language to stress the totality of the coming devastation in judgment.

questions.question: The instruction in Amos 6:10 to 'hold thy tongue' so as not to mention the name of the LORD reflects what cultural reality?
options: Fear and reverence preventing casual mention of God’s name during calamity
A prohibition against blasphemy in public
A ritual of silence during mourning
A command for priests only
questions.correctAnswer: Fear and reverence preventing casual mention of God’s name during calamity
questions.explanation: Amos 6:10 illustrates the people's fear that even naming God during catastrophe is taboo, showing their dread and diminished relationship with Him.

questions.question: Amos 6:11 foretells breaches in both 'great house' and 'little house.' This literary parallelism highlights what concept?
options: That judgment will affect all social classes
That only the wealthy will be punished
That houses will physically collapse due to earthquake
That the temple will be destroyed
questions.correctAnswer: That judgment will affect all social classes
questions.explanation: The verse uses parallelism to indicate that divine judgment is comprehensive, sparing neither the rich nor the poor.

questions.question: The rhetorical questions in Amos 6:12 ('Shall horses run upon the rock? will one plow there with oxen?') serve to illustrate what point?
options: The futility of expecting justice and righteousness in Israel
The agricultural practices of Israel
The strength of Israel’s military
The blessings of the land
questions.correctAnswer: The futility of expecting justice and righteousness in Israel
questions.explanation: These questions in Amos 6:12 symbolize the impossibility of justice and righteousness flourishing in a land corrupted by injustice.

questions.question: Amos 6:13 mentions taking 'horns' by one’s own strength. What does this 'horns' metaphor represent biblically?
options: Power and military strength
Wealth and prosperity
Wisdom and knowledge
Justice and mercy
questions.correctAnswer: Power and military strength
questions.explanation: Biblically, horns often symbolize power or strength, and here it critiques Israel’s pride in their own might apart from God.

questions.question: What is the significance of the nation raised against Israel from Hemath to the river of the wilderness in Amos 6:14?
options: It foreshadows the Assyrian conquest
It refers to a coalition of Philistines
It symbolizes Egypt’s invasion
It is a metaphor for internal rebellion
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows the Assyrian conquest
questions.explanation: Amos 6:14 predicts a devastating invasion from the north and east, historically linked to the Assyrian empire’s conquest of Israel.

questions.question: True or False: Amos 6 condemns Israel for their social injustice and complacency despite their material wealth.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The chapter consistently critiques Israel’s complacency, indulgence, and failure to care for the afflicted, as shown in multiple verses including Amos 6:4-6.

theological.title: Amos Chapter 6 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Amos Chapter 6 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the primary reason for God's judgment on those 'at ease in Zion' according to Amos 6:1-6?
options: Their complacency and luxury while ignoring the affliction of Joseph
Their open rebellion against the law of Moses
Their idolatry and worship of Baal
Their refusal to build the temple in Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Their complacency and luxury while ignoring the affliction of Joseph
questions.explanation: Amos 6:1-6 condemns those who are complacent and live in luxury ('beds of ivory', 'drink wine in bowls') and are 'not grieved for the affliction of Joseph.' This reflects God's displeasure with social injustice and spiritual neglect, consistent with Isaiah 1:11-17's denunciation of empty luxury without justice, and James 5:1-6's warning against the rich who oppress.

questions.question: In Amos 6:8, God expresses His attitude toward Jacob's 'excellency' and 'palaces.' What does He say?
options: He abhors the excellency of Jacob and hates his palaces
He delights in the excellency of Jacob and blesses his palaces
He is indifferent to the excellency of Jacob and his palaces
He will multiply the excellency of Jacob and restore his palaces
questions.correctAnswer: He abhors the excellency of Jacob and hates his palaces
questions.explanation: Amos 6:8 shows God's sovereign judgment: He abhors the pride and self-exaltation of Jacob ('the excellency of Jacob') and hates his palatial arrogance, illustrating God's holiness and opposition to human pride, paralleling Proverbs 6:16-17 and James 4:6.

questions.question: According to Amos 6:2, which cities are mentioned as a comparison to the kingdoms of Israel?
options: Calneh, Hamath, and Gath
Nineveh, Babylon, and Tyre
Jerusalem, Bethel, and Dan
Tyrus, Sidon, and Gaza
questions.correctAnswer: Calneh, Hamath, and Gath
questions.explanation: Amos 6:2 commands to visit Calneh, Hamath, and Gath to see if these kingdoms are better or have greater borders than Israel, underscoring Israel's false security and pride, a theme echoed in Jeremiah 9:23-24 and Ezekiel 16:49-50 about misplaced confidence.

questions.question: What is the consequence for those who 'put far away the evil day' as stated in Amos 6:3?
options: They bring the seat of violence near
They receive a crown of righteousness
They will be hidden in the day of wrath
They will be exalted among the nations
questions.correctAnswer: They bring the seat of violence near
questions.explanation: Amos 6:3 states that those who disregard impending judgment ('evil day') cause violence to come near, illustrating the principle of sowing and reaping (Galatians 6:7) and the reality of divine justice (Romans 12:19).

questions.question: What kind of lifestyle is described in Amos 6:4-5 that illustrates the people's indulgence?
options: Lying on ivory beds, eating lambs and calves, and playing music like David
Fasting and praying continually
Gathering the poor and feeding the hungry
Building altars for idol worship
questions.correctAnswer: Lying on ivory beds, eating lambs and calves, and playing music like David
questions.explanation: Amos 6:4-5 describes the luxurious lifestyle of the elite who indulge themselves with rich food and music, similar to the warning in Luke 16:19-31 about the rich man's neglect of justice and mercy.

questions.question: According to Amos 6:7, what will happen to those who stretch themselves in luxury?
options: They shall go captive and their banquets removed
They shall be exalted in the kingdom of God
They shall inherit the earth
They shall be rewarded for their faithfulness
questions.correctAnswer: They shall go captive and their banquets removed
questions.explanation: Amos 6:7 declares that those indulging in luxury will be taken captive and lose their banquets, illustrating divine judgment on selfishness, consistent with Matthew 25:31-46 on judgment of the indifferent wealthy.

questions.question: What does Amos 6:9 predict about the fate of men living together in one house?
options: If ten remain, they shall die
They shall be protected from harm
They will prosper and multiply
They shall rebuild the city
questions.correctAnswer: If ten remain, they shall die
questions.explanation: Amos 6:9 prophesies judgment so severe that even ten men living in one house will die, showing the extent of devastation, paralleling Ezekiel 7:15-16 and Jeremiah 14:17 about widespread destruction due to sin.

questions.question: In Amos 6:10, what does the uncle say after removing the bones from the house?
options: "Is there yet any with thee?" and then, "Hold thy tongue: for we may not mention the name of the LORD."
"The LORD is merciful and will save us."
"Rise up and rebuild the altar."
"Peace be upon this house."
questions.correctAnswer: "Is there yet any with thee?" and then, "Hold thy tongue: for we may not mention the name of the LORD."
questions.explanation: Amos 6:10 describes a scene of death and silence where even mentioning God's name is feared, reflecting the horror of judgment, akin to Habakkuk 2:20 and Revelation 15:4 where God's holiness causes reverent silence.

questions.question: What is the meaning of the 'great house' and 'little house' being smitten as per Amos 6:11?
options: Both the wealthy and poor households will suffer breaches and clefts
Only the poor will be judged
Only the leaders will be punished
The houses will be preserved and protected
questions.correctAnswer: Both the wealthy and poor households will suffer breaches and clefts
questions.explanation: Amos 6:11 indicates judgment will affect all classes—both great and small—signifying God's impartial justice, consistent with Acts 10:34 and Romans 2:11 emphasizing God's impartiality in judgment.

questions.question: What metaphor does Amos 6:12 use to describe the corruption of justice and righteousness?
options: Turning judgment into gall and fruit of righteousness into hemlock
Making justice a river of life and righteousness a tree of peace
Building houses of stone upon the rock
Plowing fields with oxen on fertile soil
questions.correctAnswer: Turning judgment into gall and fruit of righteousness into hemlock
questions.explanation: Amos 6:12 uses bitter metaphors ('gall' and 'hemlock') to illustrate the corruption of justice and righteousness, parallel to Jeremiah 9:15 and Proverbs 17:15 on perverted justice.

questions.question: Who does Amos 6:13 say rejoices in a 'thing of nought' and claims strength by their own horns?
options: Those who falsely boast of their own power and accomplishments
The prophets of Israel
The poor and oppressed
The priests and Levites
questions.correctAnswer: Those who falsely boast of their own power and accomplishments
questions.explanation: Amos 6:13 condemns those who boast falsely of their strength ('horns') by their own power, a warning against pride and self-reliance, echoing 1 Corinthians 1:31 and Jeremiah 9:23.

questions.question: What does God declare He will do in Amos 6:14 against the house of Israel?
options: Raise up a nation to afflict them from Hemath to the river of the wilderness
Bless them with peace and prosperity
Send a prophet to guide them
Restore them to their land
questions.correctAnswer: Raise up a nation to afflict them from Hemath to the river of the wilderness
questions.explanation: Amos 6:14 reveals God's eschatological judgment by raising a nation to afflict Israel, demonstrating His sovereign control over nations, consistent with Isaiah 10:5-7 and Romans 9:17.

questions.question: What is the significance of the reference to 'David' in Amos 6:5 in relation to music?
options: The people imitate David’s musical instruments but misuse them in a context of indulgence
David is praised for leading worship in righteousness
David is condemned for his sins
David's music is rejected by God
questions.correctAnswer: The people imitate David’s musical instruments but misuse them in a context of indulgence
questions.explanation: Amos 6:5 mentions inventing instruments 'like David', but in a context of self-indulgence rather than worship, illustrating the misuse of gifts, parallel to 1 Chronicles 15:16 and Psalm 150 where music is for praise, not self-indulgence.

questions.question: How does Amos 6:6 describe the people's self-care rituals?
options: Drinking wine in bowls and anointing themselves with chief ointments
Fasting and wearing sackcloth
Offering sacrifices and prayers
Living simply and humbly
questions.correctAnswer: Drinking wine in bowls and anointing themselves with chief ointments
questions.explanation: Amos 6:6 highlights excessive indulgence in luxury and self-care, contrasting with biblical calls to humility and repentance (Isaiah 58:5-7, Psalm 51:17).

questions.question: What does Amos 6:1 imply about the nations that Israel trusts in?
options: Israel is complacent trusting in their own strength and status as 'chief of the nations'
Israel trusts completely in God's protection
Israel is humble among the nations
Israel seeks alliances with foreign gods
questions.correctAnswer: Israel is complacent trusting in their own strength and status as 'chief of the nations'
questions.explanation: Amos 6:1 warns against Israel's complacency and misplaced trust in their status and mountain of Samaria, highlighting the danger of self-reliance, aligned with Psalm 20:7 and Jeremiah 17:5.
